article:
{{Infobox gridiron football person |name=Bobby Leo |image= |birth_date=
|birth_place=Everett, Massachusetts |death_date= |Position=Running back, Wide
receiver |College=Harvard University |DraftedYear=1967 |DraftedRound=7 |Stats=y
|DatabaseFootball= |PFR= |ProBowls= |years=1967-1968 |teams=Boston Patriots }}

'Bobby Leo' is a former professional American football player who played wide
receiver, tailback, kick returner, and punt returner for two seasons for the
Boston Patriots. [http://www.pro-football-
reference.com/players/L/LeoxBo00.htm Bobby Leo NFL & AFL Football Statistics -
Pro-Football-Reference.com]

He was a prominent figure on the high school gridiron in Everett, Massachusetts.
In 1999, the Boston Globe ranked the 10 best Massachusetts High School football
players of all time, and Leo ranked 3rd on the list, behind only Charlie
Brickley also of Everett and Harry Agganis of Lynn Classical. Given that both of
those two died before Leo played his high school ball, he can lay claim to being
the best living high school football player in Massachusetts history for the
past 50 years, ahead of various other prominent football players from
Massachusetts ranked behind him in the Globe analysis, including Heisman winners
Doug Flutie and Joe Bellino.

His play at Everett caught the attention of scouts from all the big name schools
at the time, and Leo was offered scholarships to Notre Dame, Michigan, and
others after his Everett squad lost a one-point game to Miami Senior High in the
"National Championship" game his senior year, when his team captured one of
their many state titles.

Leo chose to attend Harvard, where he won awards and he became the first and
only player to score the winning touchdown in the Harvard-Yale game in each of
his three varsity seasons (freshman were not eligible to play varsity in the Ivy
League at the time). He also starred in baseball and track at Harvard as he had
at Everett High School. A Sports Illustrated article in its 10/31/1966 issue
praised Leo and featured a photo and quotations from an interview with him after
an important Harvard victory against Dartmouth.

Leo earned All-Ivy honors, was named the top back in New England (the so-called
"New England Heismann" trophy), and was an honorable mention All-American. He is
a member of the Harvard Hall of Fame.

Leo's 6.3 yards per carry during his senior year were enough to place him second
in the history of Ivy League football at the time, and remains a Harvard single
season record.

He went on to be drafted by the Boston Patriots and, after serving a stint in
the military, was finally able to join the team toward the end of the season in
1967. His first game was a memorable one. On national television against the
Buffalo Bills, Leo was the primary kick and punt returner for the Patriots, and
he electrified the crowd at Fenway Park with one of the 10 longest punt returns
in the AFL that season, a 50 yard sprint past the entire Bills coverage team,
before gettting tripped up inside the ten yard line. Later in the game, he took
his first professional handoff from the running back slot for 7 yards. Late in
the game he lined up a wide receiver. His first professional reception was a 25-
yard touchdown in the final moments of the game. He continued to play a primary
role on the Patriots' return team, effectively returning punts and kickoffs the
following week at the Orange Bowl against the Miami Dolphins.

The following season he was slotted to be one of the Patriots' primary tail
backs, and was listed as second of five players on the depth chart in the team's
official media guide. During the long preseason (which was 6 games at the time),
the coaching staff decided to move him back to receiver, with great success. He
had a strong preseason that year. Against a the Jets in a preseason game in
Richmond, Virginia, he caught four passes and was moved to the starting lineup
the following week against the Dolphins. He concluded his successful preseason
at flanker by scoring in an AFL v. NFL exhibition game against the Philadelphia
Eagles at his old stomping grounds, Harvard Stadium, and serving as the team's
primary kick returner during that time. After returning kicks in the first game
of the regular season, Leo suffered a serious injury in an ensuing practice
before the next regular season game, during the two week layoff as a result of a
bye week for the Patriots in week 2 of the regular season. The Patrios were
required to make a roster move because their primary punter was hurt as well,
and asked Leo to accept a temporary assignment to the taxi squad after he
recovered from his injury. Leo refused, and retired from the game.

He amassed over 300 total yards during his tenure for the Patriots.

After the 1968 season, Bobby decided to return to academics, attending law
school in the Boston area and practicing law for many years thereafter.
